content:
Located in the southern Peloponnesian peninsula, Pavlopetri (the modern name of the site) emerged as a Neolithic settlement around 3500 B.C. and became an important trading center for Mycenaean Greece (1650-1180 B.C.). This area of the Aegean Sea is <question_0> to earthquakes and tsunamis, which caused the city to <question_1> sink. The slow sea level rise in Mediterranean <question_2> this city around 3000 years ago.

For millennia, the city's <question_3> lay unseen below some 13 feet of water. They were covered by a thick layer of sand <question_4> the island of Laconia. In recent decades, shifting <question_5> and climate change have eroded a natural barrier that <question_6> Pavlopetri. In 1967 a scientific survey of the Peloponnesian coast was <question_7> data to analyze changes in sea levels <question_8> British oceanographer Nicholas Flemming first spotted the sunken <question_9>. A year later, he returned with a few students to <question_10> the location and map the site. <question_11> the exciting initial finds, the site would lie <question_12> for decades before archaeologists would return.

In 2009 archaeologists Chrysanthi Gallou and Jon Henderson <question_13> the excavation of Pavlopetri in cooperation with the Greek Ministry of Culture. Since the 1960s, underwater archaeology <question_14> and tools had made huge advances. The team <question_15> robotics, sonar mapping, and state-of-the-art graphics to survey the site. From 2009 to 2013 they were able to bring the underwater town to <question_16>. Covering about two and a half acres, Pavlopetri's three main roads <question_17> some 50 rectangular buildings, all of which had open courtyards. Excavations revealed a large number of Minoan-style loom weights, <question_18> Pavlopetri was a thriving trade center with a <question_19> textile industry.
